clinical_study.brief_title: Assessing Pain, Patient Reported Outcomes and Complementary and Integrative Health
clinical_study.official_title: Complementary and Integrative Health for Pain in the VA: A National Demonstration Project (NIH-VA-DOD Joint Initiative)

lead_sponsor.agency: VA Office of Research and Development

collaborator.agency: Veterans Health Administration Office of Patient Centered Care & Cultural Transformation

clinical_study.source: VA Office of Research and Development

brief_summary.textblock: The APPROACH Study (Assessing Pain, Patient-Reported Outcomes and Complementary and Integrative Health) assesses the effects of use of 1) practitioner-delivered CIH therapies alone or 2) self-care CIH therapies alone compared to 3) the combination of self-care and practitioner-delivered CIH therapies among Veterans with chronic musculoskeletal pain. The APPROACH study is predominately conducting a secondary analysis of patient-reported data being collected by the Veterans Health Administration's (VA) Office of Patient Centered Care and Cultural Transformation among Veterans using 18 VA medical centers. Those facilities received funding as part of the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act to expand availability of CIH therapies. That patient-reported data is being supplemented with VA electronic health record data and data on the 18 medical centers' business practices (nudges, the instrumental variable). Practitioner-delivered therapies under study include chiropractic care, acupuncture and therapeutic massage, and self-care therapies include Tai Chi/qigong, yoga and meditation. The primary outcomes are improvement in pain severity and pain interference, using the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI), 6 months after initiating CIH therapies compared to baseline. Patients will enter treatment groups based on the CIH therapies they use, as randomizing patients to specific therapies would require withholding therapies routinely offered at VA. The investigators will address selection bias and confounding by using sites' variations in business practices and other encouragements (nudges) to receiving different CIH therapies as a surrogate for direct randomization using instrumental variables econometric methods.

detailed_description.textblock:
Design: The investigators are employing a quasi-experimental encouragement study design in which subjects are able to choose their own CIH therapies, but some are offered extra encouragements (nudges) to choose specific CIH therapies. Instead of being randomized to a CIH therapy, individuals will enter one of the three study groups based on what CIH therapies they used six months after they initiate any CIH therapy. Although accrual to study group is not random, some sites have strong business practices/nudges that lead to considerable variation in which CIH therapies patients use. The variation induced by these business practices/nudges provides a quasi-experimental natural experiment that can be assessed through an instrumental variables analytic approach. The purpose of using business practices as an instrument for accruing patients to treatment group, similar to the use of randomization, is to reduce potential selection and confounding bias. The 6-month treatment window will allow for patients to initiate one type of CIH therapy and add additional CIH therapies based on business practices/nudges at their site within the evaluation period. The CIH therapies that patients receive will be as they are delivered by the 18 VHA Whole Health flagship study sites and community care practices.
Sites: The study sites are the VA's 18 Whole Health Flagship sites: VA Boston Health Care System, VA New Jersey Health Care System, Erie VAMC, Beckley VAMC, W. G. (Bill) Hefner VAMC, Atlanta VAMC, Tampa VAMC, Tennessee Valley Health Care System, Aleda E. Lutz VAMC, Tomah VAMC, St. Louis VA Health Care System, Central Arkansas Veterans Healthcare System, South Texas Veterans Health Care System, Salt Lake City VAMC, VA Portland Health Care System, Palo Alto VAMC, Tucson VAMC, VA Nebraska-Western Iowa Health Care System).
Secondary Data from the CIH Experience Survey/ VA Office of Patient Centered Care and Cultural Transformation's Survey: The APPROACH study is predominately conducting a secondary analysis of patient-reported data being collected by VA OPCC&CT's survey. That is a 4-time point survey (baseline and months 1, 3, 6). Almost all of the outcomes listed below are from that survey.

primary_outcome.description: Measure of pain-related functional interference. Scores range 0-10; higher score is worse.
Measure of pain intensity. Scores range 0-10; higher score is worse.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) for improvement in pain
Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) for improvement in mental health
Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) for improvement in physical health
Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) for improvement in fatigue
Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) for improvement in overall well-being
PROMIS10 global assessment of physical health
secondary_outcome.description: Items are rated on a five-point scale with higher scores indicating better health.

secondary_outcome.measure: PROMIS10 global assessment of mental health
secondary_outcome.description: Items are rated on a five-point scale with higher scores indicating better health.
Items are rated on a five-point scale with higher scores indicating better health.

secondary_outcome.measure: PROMIS10 assessment of general quality of life
secondary_outcome.description: Items are rated on a five-point scale with higher scores indicating better health.
Measure of general purpose in life
Measure of depressed mood and anhedonia. Scores range from 0 to 6, with higher scores indicating more depressive symptoms.

other_outcome.description: To assess perceived health competence as a mechanism of action
To assess ownership of one's own health as a mechanism of action
Using 2 out of 6 items to assess self-efficacy as a mechanism of action

arm_group.arm_group_label: Veterans using practitioner delivered CIH therapies only
arm_group.description: Veterans using practitioner-delivered (acupuncture, chiropractic care, massage) CIH therapies only

arm_group.arm_group_label: Veterans using self-care CIH therapies only
arm_group.description: Veterans using self-care (yoga, meditation, Tai Chi, Qi Gong) CIH therapies only

arm_group.arm_group_label: Veterans using a combination of practitioner-delivered and self-care CIH therapies (dual-care)
arm_group.description: Veterans using a combination of practitioner-delivered and self-care CIH therapies (dual-care)

intervention.intervention_name: Practitioner-delivered CIH therapies (acupuncture, therapeutic massage, chiropractic care) as received in VHA and community practice settings
intervention.description: Practitioner-delivered CIH therapies (acupuncture, therapeutic massage, chiropractic care) as received in VHA and community practice settings
intervention.arm_group_label: Veterans using practitioner delivered CIH therapies only

intervention.intervention_name: Self-care CIH therapies (yoga, Tai Chi/Qigong , meditation) as received in VHA and community practice settings
intervention.description: Self-care CIH therapies (yoga, Tai Chi/Qigong , meditation) as received in VHA and community practice settings
intervention.arm_group_label: Veterans using self-care CIH therapies only

intervention.intervention_name: Combination of practitioner-delivered and self-care CIH therapies (described above) as received in VHA and community practice settings
intervention.description: Combination of practitioner-delivered and self-care CIH therapies (described above) as received in VHA and community practice settings
intervention.arm_group_label: Veterans using a combination of practitioner-delivered and self-care CIH therapies (dual-care)

study_pop.textblock: Patients with moderate to severe chronic musculoskeletal pain who initiate at least one of the six CIH therapies at the 18 VA Whole Health flagship study sites during the study period who also participate in the VA Office of Patient Centered Care and Cultural Transformation?s CIH Experience Survey.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Veteran
- History of (chronic) musculoskeletal-related pain conditions recorded in the EHR in the year prior to the index visit, and self-report pain present every day or nearly every day for 3 months from the CIH index visit using an eligibility screener
- 18-89 on index CIH visit date
Exclusion Criteria:
- diagnoses of serious mental illness in the year prior to initiating CIH
- history of spinal cord injury
- hospitalization 30 days prior to initiating CIH
- recorded CIH use in the EHR in the 6 months prior to the index CIH visit and reported CIH use in the 8 weeks prior to index CIH visit

overall_official.affiliation: VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System, Sepulveda, CA

facility.name: VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System, Sepulveda, CA
VA Puget Sound Health Care System Seattle Division, Seattle, WA

results_reference.citation: Zeliadt SB, Coggeshall S, Thomas E, Gelman H, Taylor SL. The APPROACH trial: Assessing pain, patient-reported outcomes, and complementary and integrative health. Clin Trials. 2020 Aug;17(4):351-359. doi: 10.1177/1740774520928399. Epub 2020 Jun 10.

Zeliadt SB, Coggeshall S, Gelman H, Shin MH, Elwy AR, Bokhour BG, Taylor SL. Assessing the Relative Effectiveness of Combining Self-Care with Practitioner-Delivered Complementary and Integrative Health Therapies to Improve Pain in a Pragmatic Trial. Pain Med. 2020 Dec 12;21(Suppl 2):S100-S109. doi: 10.1093/pm/pnaa349.

patient_data.ipd_description: The APPROACH study is primarily a study of existing data. As such, the investigators will not have data to share.
